channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Biden and Leaders of Egypt and Qatar to Offer ‘Final’ Cease-Fire Deal Next Week
item.description: “The time has come,” said a joint statement by the three, whose teams have led indirect negotiations between Israel and Hamas. Israel agreed to send a delegation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Arab and Western Nations Urge Restraint as Israel-Iran Tensions Simmer
item.description: Trying to head off a Middle East war, several countries are pressing Iran to temper its retaliation for the assassination of a Hamas leader in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Ben Hubbard, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A banner showing the Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh, left, who was killed in an assassination last week, joining hands with Iran’s new president, Masoud Pezeshkian, in Tehran, Iran, on Monday.

item.title: In a Surprise, Ukraine Advances on Russian Region of Kursk
item.description: The local government in the Russian region of Kursk declared a state of emergency as military analysts reported that Ukrainian forces had advanced several miles across the border.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A photo provided by the acting governor in the Kursk region of Russia shows a house this week that was damaged by Ukrainian shelling.

item.title: How Anti-Immigrant Riots Flared in the U.K.
item.description: A far-right movement fueled by disinformation has brought fear and violence to cities across England and in Northern Ireland. That has in turn prompted counterprotests.
item.dc:creator: Nader Ibrahim and Peter Robins
item.media:description: In Rotherham, the police struggled to fend off rioters attacking a hotel.

item.title: U.K. Officials Express Relief After Far-Right Riots Fail to Materialize
item.description: The authorities had been braced for further violence after anti-immigrant demonstrations in previous days had descended into riots.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Liverpool, England, on Wednesday. With around 6,000 police on standby across Britain, the evening passed with little violence.

item.title: 2 Youths Planned Attacks on Taylor Swift’s Vienna Concerts, Authorities Say
item.description: A suspect confessed to a plot using explosives and other weapons to kill as many attendees as possible, security officials said. The singer’s three-concert Vienna run was canceled.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Visitors talked to security staff outside the Ernst Happel Stadium in Vienna on Thursday after all three Taylor Swift concerts set to take place there were canceled.

item.title: Chinese Woman Loses Legal Challenge for Right to Freeze Her Eggs
item.description: Despite a declining birthrate that has alarmed the nation’s leaders, regulations in China prevent unmarried women from freezing their eggs.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Teresa Xu outside the Chaoyang court in 2021, before a hearing in her case against a hospital that rejected her request to freeze eggs.

item.title: Why Kenya Stopped Running From Its Doping Past
item.description: A nation synonymous with distance running was given a multimillion-dollar choice: Get serious about antidoping efforts, or get banned from world sports.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Kenyan runners at a meet in Nairobi in 2018.

item.title: Olympic Medals Offer Ukraine a Brief Respite From War
item.description: Ukraine has won 10 medals so far at the Paris Olympics. Each has been celebrated in the war-torn country as a symbol of resilience and defiance.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Khyzhniak celebrated after winning the gold medal at the Paris Olympics on Wednesday.

item.title: Muhammad Yunus Set to Lead Bangladesh Temporarily
item.description: Muhammad Yunus, as interim leader, faces the daunting task of restoring order in a country gripped by violence and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Mohammed Shahabuddin, center, administering the oath of office late Thursday to Muhammad Yunus, in a vest at right, in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Carles Puigdemont Returns to Catalonia, Defying Spanish Arrest Warrant
item.description: Large crowds greeted the former regional leader, who has lived in self-imposed exile since a failed 2017 independence bid. Despite a new amnesty law, he could still face arrest.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia’s separatist leader-in-exile, returned to Barcelona on Thursday.

item.title: Tsunami Warning Issued in Japan After Strong Earthquakes
item.description: The official warning came after a 7.1-magnitude temblor struck off the coast of southern Japan on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya, Hisako Ueno and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Visitors to the Nagasaki Peace Park in western Japan as an earthquake alert was issued on Thursday.

item.title: Jake Paul Lends His Celebrity (Some of It) to Olympic Boxing
item.description: Paul, a social media influencer and boxer, usually promotes professional fighting. Now he’s in a partnership with U.S.A. Boxing, but his output in Paris has been minimal.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan and Ryan Lowry

item.title: Israel Prepares for Expected Attacks by Iran and Hezbollah
item.description: Israel advised people to stock up on food and water in fortified safe rooms, while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told soldiers that Israel is “prepared for defense, as well as offense.”
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Tel Aviv on Thursday. Israel is on high alert.

item.title: Sydney McLaughlin breaks her own 400-meter hurdle record. Again.
item.description: Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone broke her own world record on her way to winning gold for the United States in the 400 meter hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Chang W. Lee, Gabriela Bhaskar and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Jacques Lewis, French Veteran of U.S. Landing on D-Day, Dies at 105
item.description: Believed to be the last surviving Frenchman to wade ashore with Americans, he was attached to an Army unit that stormed Utah Beach and helped drive Germans out of France.
item.dc:creator: Phil Davison
item.media:description: Jacques Lewis on June 8 attending a ceremony at the Arc de Triomphe in Paris marking the 80th anniversary of D-Day.

item.title: Noah Lyles Wins Bronze in 200 Meters, Then Reveals He Has Covid
item.description: Lyles said he started feeling ill two days ago and knew it was more than just soreness from winning the 100. In Paris, there are no testing requirements, and national governing bodies develop their own protocols.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: Noah Lyles struggled after finishing third in the men’s 200-meter dash.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Trump and Harris Agreed to Debate
item.description: Plus, how Olympians get paid.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida yesterday.

item.title: Every 4 Years, Timmy McCarthy Gives Ireland a Reason to Watch Basketball
item.description: While the Irish have no team in the Olympic tournament, Timmy McCarthy’s eccentric, enthusiastic commentary has earned him his own fervent fan base.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: Taylor Swift Fans Commiserate in Vienna After Concerts Are Canceled
item.description: Taylor Swift fans from around the world grappled with disappointment and fear after a terrorism plot derailed the Vienna dates of the Eras Tour.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Fans in central Vienna on Thursday. The planned concerts had been estimated to draw 200,000 Swifties from around the world.

item.title: Free Haircuts and Manicures for Athletes at the Olympic Village Salon
item.description: At the Olympic Village, cuts, styles and manicures are free. The benefits, the athletes say, are priceless.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Athletes at the salon in the Olympic Village in St.-Ouen-sur-Seine, France.

item.title: U.S. ‘Dissatisfied’ With China’s Disclosures About Stabbings
item.description: The U.S. ambassador has criticized the handling of an attack on four instructors from an American college, but China’s foreign ministry called it an “isolated incident.”
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Park visitors in Jilin City, China, walking past the wall near where four instructors from an American college were stabbed on June 10.

item.title: Who Are the S.P.L.M., the Rebel Group Fighting for Democracy in Sudan?
item.description: We embedded with an elusive rebel group in the Nuba Mountains to document its side of the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey

item.title: What’s It Like to Be Drug-Tested? We Asked Three Olympic Runners.
item.description: It will never feel normal, athletes said, to have a stranger knock on your door and ask for a vial of your blood. Or some urine.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Materials for an antidoping test. Track athletes must provide their locations so they can be tested without advance notice.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Antiracism protesters in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A demonstration in London yesterday against a planned anti-immigrant protest.

item.title: Why the Dutch Field Hockey Team Isn’t Shaking Hands at the Olympics
item.description: After two pandemic-disrupted Olympics, most teams haven’t given Covid a second thought in Paris. The one from the Netherlands is the exception.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith, Talya Minsberg and Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: The Netherlands team has avoided handshakes with competitors at the Olympics.

item.title: Trying to Capitalize on Anti-Migrant Riots Could Backfire on U.K.’s Far Right
item.description: The public’s reaction to the recent rioting has been resoundingly negative, suggesting that using the unrest to push anti-immigrant policies could backfire, at least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Holding back demonstrators during disorder in Southport, northwestern England, last week.

item.title: Feud Flares Between U.S. and Global Antidoping Agency
item.description: American officials allowed athletes to compete after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs so they could work undercover. Their global counterparts call that a breach of the rules.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: “Clean athletes deserve answers, and they deserve better from WADA,” said Travis Tygart, the head of the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency, referring to the global doping watchdog.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Antiracism Protesters Gather in Britain
item.description: Plus, China’s quest for Olympic gold shifts gears.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: North Finchley, a suburb of London, yesterday.

item.title: For These Olympians, the Bling Is the Thing
item.description: Athletes at the Paris Olympics have been sporting some seriously high-wattage accessories. Here are nine of our favorites.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: Sha’Carri Richardson showed off the nails she wore during the opening ceremony.

item.title: How China’s Quest for Olympic Gold Has Evolved
item.description: A young skater’s emergence signals a pivot in the way an Olympic power defines success. But its handling of the table tennis competition suggests old expectations may persist, too.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: As Iran Braces for War, Its Citizens Are Kept in the Dark
item.description: Iranians say they have not been told how to prepare should broad hostilities break out between their country and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran showing Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas leader who was assassinated last week, with Iran’s newly elected president, Masoud Pezeshkian.

item.title: 30 Months After Their Games Ended, U.S. Figure Skaters Get Golds
item.description: In a ceremony in Paris, the American team received the medals they won after the Russian skater Kamila Valieva was disqualified.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The members of the U.S. figure skating team with their gold medals from the 2022 Olympics.

item.title: As Biden’s Presidency Wanes, U.S. and Asian Nations Do a Delicate Dance
item.description: On an epic trip, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken tried to reassure Asian leaders about American commitments. But China remains the enduring backyard behemoth.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: During the trip, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, alongside Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, injected some confidence into U.S. military alliances with Japan and the Philippines.

item.title: At the Olympics, Artistic Swimmers Flip, Twist and Push for Respect
item.description: Artistic swimming is a crowd-pleaser and much harder than it used to be, but it has had to make the case that it is even a sport at all.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artistic swimming is one of the flashiest, and oddest, sports at the Games.

item.title: Connie Chiume, 72, Dies; ‘Black Panther’ Actor Bridged S. Africa Eras
item.description: Her career began during apartheid and outlived it, reaching a personal milestone in a blockbuster movie and its sequel.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Connie Chiume during the world premiere of “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” in Hollywood in 2022. She played an honored elder of a mining tribe in a fictional African kingdom.

item.title: Hotel Collapse in Germany Kills 2 and Prompts Frantic Rescue Mission
item.description: The last living person was saved from the rubble on Wednesday after a centuries-old structure collapsed the night before.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: Rescue workers outside the Reichsschenke Zum Ritter Götz hotel in Kröv, Germany. Several people were rescued after a second floor collapsed on Tuesday.

item.title: Counterprotesters Gather in U.K. After Anti-Immigrant Riots
item.description: Extra police officers were mobilized across the country, but by Wednesday evening, there were no signs of large far-right protests.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered in Liverpool, England, on Wednesday to demonstrate against racism.

item.title: Heat Raises Fears of ‘Demise’ for Great Barrier Reef Within a Generation
item.description: A new study found that temperatures in the Coral Sea have reached their highest levels in at least four centuries.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: A marine biologist inspected bleached coral near Lizard Island on the Great Barrier Reef this year.

item.title: In Prisoner Swap, Echoes of Putin’s K.G.B. Past
item.description: A sprawling exchange with the West underscored the Russian president’s loyalty to his intelligence services. It also showed his continued interest in making deals.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s past with the K.G.B. is core to his identity as Russia’s leader. That was evident in last week’s prisoner exchange.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Skip Peace Ceremony in Japan Over Israel’s Omission
item.description: The American and British ambassadors to Japan said they would not attend an event to mark the atomic bomb strike in Nagasaki because Israel’s ambassador was excluded.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Doves flying at an annual peace ceremony in Nagasaki, Japan, in 2022, on the anniversary of the American atomic bombing of the city.

item.title: Ukraine Launches Rare Cross-Border Ground Assault Into Russia
item.description: Troops and armored fighting vehicles crossed into Russia’s western Kursk region on Tuesday, according to Moscow and independent analysts. Ukrainian officials have not commented.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Acting Governor Of Kursk Region Alexei Smirnov, via Reuters
item.media:description: A destroyed house, shown in a photograph made available by the acting governor of Russia’s Kursk region after what the local authorities said was a Ukrainian cross-border attack on Tuesday.

item.title: Hindus in Bangladesh Face Revenge Attacks After Hasina’s Ouster
item.description: There has long been a perception that the Hindu minority supports Sheikh Hasina, who resigned her post and fled the country after a popular uprising.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Qasim Nauman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Anti-government protesters have targeted the offices of the Awami League, the party of the ousted prime minister, Sheikh Hasina.

item.title: Court Disbands Thailand’s Most Popular Political Party
item.description: Since the Move Forward Party won the last election with a call for change, conservative forces have kept it out of power. Now, it no longer exists.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, the Move Forward Party’s former leader, in Parliament in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: Fear Stalks Israel’s Communities on the Front Lines With Lebanon
item.description: As tensions again escalate with Hezbollah, Israelis face the prospect of another “lost year” in the evacuated north.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier entering a bomb shelter in the evacuated Kibbutz Snir in northern Israel, near the border with Lebanon.

item.title: How Belarus Was Left Out of a Prisoner Swap Between Russia and the West
item.description: While Belarus played a role in the sweeping prisoner exchange last week, none of the 1,400 people classified as political prisoners in the country by a human rights group were freed.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, second from right, held a photo of her jailed husband, Sergei Tikhanovsky, during a protest in Vilnius, Lithuania, in March. Others held photos of other Belarusian opposition figures.

item.title: After French Rail Sabotage, Some See Signs of a Murky ‘Ultraleft’
item.description: Experts say the arson attacks before the opening of the Paris Olympics bear the hallmarks of insurrectionary anarchists opposed to the state.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling outside the Gare du Nord station. There have been no arrests for the coordinated arson attacks that briefly disrupted rail travel for hundreds of thousands of travelers before the Olympics opened.

item.title: Indian Wrestler Vinesh Phogat Disqualified From Paris Olympics Gold Medal Match
item.description: The wrestler Vinesh Phogat had a chance to become the first woman from India to win an Olympic gold, but she was disqualified when she missed her weight class by a few ounces.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Suhasini Raj and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Vinesh Phogat of India competing in a semifinal on Tuesday.

item.title: Suga, of BTS, Apologizes for Riding Electric Scooter While Drunk
item.description: The artist’s driver’s license was revoked and he may face disciplinary action after failing a breath test, his agency said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Suga, a member of the K-pop group BTS, in 2022.

item.title: With ‘Sprint’ and ‘Simone Biles: Rising,’ Netflix Fills Olympic Content Gap
item.description: New seasons of documentaries about running, gymnastics and basketball are being filmed this summer as part of a partnership with the International Olympic Committee.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A documentary crew for Netflix filmed American track and field athletes during a morning practice in Eaubonne, France, near Paris, last week.

item.title: Capturing the Split Seconds Between Victory and Defeat
item.description: Faced with the challenge of quickly recapping Olympic events, The Times creates its own animated versions of competitions. The internet loves them.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Nick Bartzokas, Alice Fang, John Huang, and Eden Weingart/The New York Times
item.media:description: For the past five Olympic Games, The Times has animated events from sports including track and field to help readers get caught up to speed.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s choice for vice president.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with Tim Walz in Philadelphia on Tuesday.

item.title: Does a Speedsuit Make You Faster? Maybe. Does It Look Cool? Absolutely.
item.description: Once an outfit strictly worn by sprinters, the single-piece speedsuit has become common among middle-distance runners. Its efficacy is beside the point.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway, right, has helped popularize speedsuits in the 1,500 meters. His brother Henrik pioneered the use of the suits in middle-distance running.

item.title: Can You Heal Olympic Heartbreak With Belated Medals?
item.description: A weight lifter walked away from his sport after a bitter loss in 2012. He and other athletes, including a U.S. figure skating team, will receive their medals in Paris.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeon competing in the London Olympics. After his Russian rival, Ruslan Albegov, secured third place, Jeon returned home and started a new life.

item.title: Olympic Boxer Imane Khelif Will Fight For a Gold Medal On Friday
item.description: Imane Khelif, of Algeria, moved past questions about her eligibility with a unanimous decision over her Thai opponent. She will now fight for a gold medal.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Imane Khelif of Algeria, right, won her semifinal match against Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand on Tuesday.

item.title: Hamas Elevates Gaza Leader Who Planned Oct. 7 Attacks to Top Post
item.description: The selection of Yahya Sinwar, a prime target of Israeli forces, to replace the assassinated Ismail Haniyeh consolidates authority in the hands of a hard-liner who is in hiding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar will replace Ismail Haniyeh as the next head of Hamas’s political office. He is seen here in Gaza City in 2023.

item.title: Who Is Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s New Political Leader?
item.description: Mr. Sinwar, one of the main architects of the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel, has spent decades with the militant group, working his way to the top of its leadership.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, in Gaza City in 2023, has long been viewed as one of Hamas’s most influential leaders, wielding outsize power while remaining mostly in hiding in underground tunnels.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Harris Picked a Running Mate
item.description: Plus, how breaking made it to the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Walz’s rural roots, liberal policies and buzzy takedowns of Donald Trump put him on the map.

item.title: Bangladesh Prime Minister’s Sheikh Hasina’s Chaotic Final Hours
item.description: As masses of people converged, angry at the killing of protesters, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina insisted that she could hold on, which military leaders said would mean spilling far more blood.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Shayeza Walid and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A vandalized image of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in the aftermath of her hasty departure from Bangladesh.

item.title: It took 14 years and 86 days to make an Olympic champion in skateboarding.
item.description: Arisa Trew vaulted into first place with her final run, winning gold.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
